Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Situation2: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today, and I am the leader of the session.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Tan’s voice rose, sharp and suspicious. “How do I know this isn’t a scam? I’ve been with your company for years, and now you want my details again?” My script urged me to reassure, to persist, to turn his objections into a sale. My supervisor’s words echoed: “Don’t let them off the line. Handle every question. Close the deal.” But my eyes flicked to the clock—ten minutes until the meditation group gathered, waiting for me to guide them in stillness and compassion. I was supposed to be calm, present, a model of mindfulness. Yet my heart thudded, torn between the demand to persuade and the call to lead with peace. Mr. Tan’s frustration pressed in, my own breath growing shallow. I pictured the quiet room, the gentle chime, the expectant faces. But here I was, tethered to the headset, caught between the world’s noise and the silence I longed to share.
